repnme.cdata!: Uganda - Small Towns Water and Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory,
            with project sustainability likely. The overall performance
            of both the World Bank and the Borrower are rated
            satisfactory. These are the some of the lessons identified
            from this project. Proper demand assessment would have led
            to curtailing the over-design of systems. Project design and
            costing needs to include mechanisms for financing
            connections to ensure adequate secondary and tertiary
            distribution infrastructure is developed from the outset, a
            large customer base, and a balance between production and
            distribution - linking investments with cost recovery,
            revenue generation and debt service. Lending large amounts
            of capital for investments to a utility requires full
            technical, financial, economic and institutional analyses as
            a basis for justification. Quality assurance during
            preparation is key--this may have helped define clearer
            objectives, addressing the mismatch between the components
            and objectives, preparing more appropriate levels of
            investment and better demand assessment. Collect adequate
            baseline data and information to allow for a clearer
            assessment of project impacts. Small towns should be treated
            as simplified urban utilities rather than as an upgraded
            rural system. Application of the water user association
            (WUA) model in urban towns is inappropriate because: the
            demand responses in urban town, however small, call for more
            commercial management of different service levels  not
            anticipated in the original design; governance arrangements
            at Town Council level introduce complications in ownership
            of assets, management oversight and day-to-day operation of
            the systems.. WUAs need to be strengthened with adequate
            resources and manpower to provide more structured and timely
            support and to guide Urban Water Authorities in the
            planning, design, construction and regulation of operation
            and maintenance and supervision of the Private operators.
            To avoid delays in project implementation, conditionality,
            which is outside the control of implementing agencies,
            should be avoided. The requirement to formalize the
            existence of Water User Groups, Water User Associations, and
            Water and Sanitation Committees required the enactment of
            the Water Statute by Parliament; this condition led to a
            15-month delay in project effectiveness.  Financial
            viability of a utility and sustainability of services
            delivery depends on appropriate dimensioning and balance
            between production, secondary and tertiary infrastructure,
            coupled with sound commercial and financial management.
            Monitoring and evaluation systems need to be developed for
            the operational and financial performance of the town water
            authorities, in order to review accuracy of data, and to
            prepare short-term financial forecast and action plans and a
            feedback mechanism to improve management especially at this
            stage when the Towns Boards are in their nascent stage.
            Good quality preparation, vigilance of the engineering
            consultant and the project management team throughout the
            project cycle are important elements that guarantee quality,
            limit delays and over design of systems, and provide a good
            basis for sustainable operations. scope and size of
            investments should consider the viability of the utility and
            the impact of the investment on its balance sheet. Timely
            review of projects performance and progress is needed to
            take corrective measures. Task teams should take advantage
            of project restructuring as an opportunity to fundamentally
            improve projects including re-definition of objectives,
            components and to request necessary assessments that would
            make for better project outputs, outcomes and impacts.

18156806.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Urban development,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!: Uganda - Small Towns Water and Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will support the
            government's economic recovery program by extending the
            rehabilitation and upgrading of water supply and sanitation
            services to towns that have so far not been covered. It
            will: (a) improve health conditions through better water
            supply, excreta disposal, waste water management, and public
            hygiene; (b) alleviate poverty and improve the lot of women;
            and (c) reduce environmental degradation through better
            waste management. The project will provide 12 small towns
            and Jinja with improved and sustainable water supply and
            sanitation through: (a) the rehabilitation and/or expansion
            of water supply and sanitation facilities; (b) hygiene
            education related to water supply and sanitation; (c)
            community participation in planning, implementation,
            operation, and maintenance of water supply and sanitation
            facilities; and (d) institutional strengthening, technical
            assistance and training for the organizations in the sector.

docna.cdata!: Uganda - Small Towns Water and Sanitation Project
